questions.text: Which of the following cardioselective beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisoprolol

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been clinically proven to reduce mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF). It works by decreasing the heart rate, reducing myocardial oxygen demand, and limiting the harmful effects of sympathetic nervous system activation in heart failure. Along with metoprolol and carvedilol, bisoprolol is one of the few beta-blockers approved for use in CHF due to its demonstrated benefits in reducing mortality and improving patient outcomes.

 

Remember - Drugs that decrease mortality are primarily those that inhibit the renin-angiotensin pathway, including beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, ARBs (angiotensin II receptor blockers), and angiotensin receptor blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is not typically used in the management of CHF due to its lack of cardioselectivity. It has not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with CHF.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking properties. While it is useful in the management of hypertensive emergencies, it is not used for chronic management of CHF and has not been shown to decrease mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Pindolol: Pindolol is another non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA). It is not suitable for CHF management and does not have evidence supporting a mortality benefit in heart failure patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure.

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change
Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment

questions.text: Which is the Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ministry of Home Affairs

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India. The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs, with the Prime Minister serving as its chairperson. The nodal center for disaster management is at the district level.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ministry of Health and Family Welfare: While this ministry plays a role in health-related aspects of disasters, it is not the nodal ministry for overall disaster management.

 

Option C. Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change: This ministry deals with environmental aspects but is not responsible for coordinating disaster management activities.

 

Option D. Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment: This ministry focuses on social welfare programs but does not coordinate disaster management activities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs serves as the nodal ministry for disaster management in India, with the district being the nodal center for implementation. NDMA functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs with the Prime Minister as its chairperson.

questions.text: A two-year-old boy presents with delayed speech, difficulties in communication, and repetitive behaviors such as staring at his own hands. He struggles with making friends and concentrating. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Autism

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Autism (now classified as Autism Spectrum Disorder in current diagnostic systems). The key features presented in this case include:

  1. Delayed speech and difficulties in communication (language impairment)
  2. Repetitive behaviors (staring at hands) which represent restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior
  3. Social interaction difficulties (struggles with making friends)
  4. Age of presentation before 3 years (the child is 2 years old)

 

These symptoms align perfectly with the core diagnostic criteria of autism, which includes impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often seen in autism.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. ADHD (Incorrect): While ADHD can present with concentration difficulties, it typically doesn't include speech delays, repetitive behaviors, or social interaction difficulties as primary symptoms. ADHD is characterized primarily by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. 
  • Option C. Mental Retardation (Incorrect): Now termed Intellectual Disability, this condition involves below-average intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior. While intellectual disability can co-occur with autism (around 30% of cases), the repetitive behaviors and specific social interaction difficulties described are more characteristic of autism than isolated intellectual disability.
  • Option D. Specific Learning Disability (Incorrect): Learning disabilities involve difficulties in specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) out of proportion to the intellectual functioning of the child. They aren't typically diagnosed in toddlers as these skills aren't yet expected, and they don't explain the communication deficits, repetitive behaviors, or social difficulties described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autism is characterized by impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often present in autism. These symptoms typically manifest before age 3, making early identification possible.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classical histological feature of Lichen Planus? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Munro microabscess.

 

  • This is not a feature of lichen planus. 
  • Munro microabscesses are collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum, and are a hallmark of psoriasis, not lichen planus. 

 

 

  • Their presence helps differentiate psoriasis from lichenoid dermatoses histologically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Max Joseph Cleft:

 

  • The Max Joseph space is an artifactual cleft that forms at the dermo-epidermal junction due to the extensive basal cell damage in lichen planus.

 

Option B. Civatte bodies:

 

  • Civatte bodies (also called colloid bodies) are apoptotic keratinocytes that appear as eosinophilic, rounded structures in the lower epidermis and papillary dermis of lichen planus lesions.

 

Option C. Sawtooth profile of rete ridges:

 

  • The sawtooth appearance of the rete ridges is characteristic of lichen planus and results from the irregular acanthosis combined with basal cell damage.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Munro microabscesses are a classical histological feature of psoriasis, not lichen planus, which is characterized by Max Joseph clefts, Civatte bodies, and sawtooth rete ridges.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

  • Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors available on the surface of liver cells, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. It is used for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that works by reducing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. It is used to lower LDL cholesterol levels but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3), which reduces levels of triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, and other lipids. It is used for treating homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor used primarily as an immunosuppressant in transplant patients and in certain types of cancer. It is not related to cholesterol metabolism and is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of bronchial asthma in third stage of labor. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carboprost

 

The drug that should be avoided in this patient with a history of bronchial asthma is carboprost since it can cause bronchoconstriction.

 

Carboprost (PGF2α analogue)

 

Action - It increases uterine tone by contracting upper segment of uterus

 

Use - To control postpartum hemorrhage (DOC – Oxytocin).

 

A/E - Vomiting, diarrhea, and bronchoconstriction.

 

Contraindications -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH and also used in augmentation of labour according to WHO guidelines. Administered by intravenous route and may lead to hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and in atony treatment. It should be avoided in patients with a history of asthma, glaucoma, or myocardial infarction. One major adverse effect is uterine hyperstimulation.

 

Option D. Methyl ergometrine: Ergot derivatives are used in the control of postpartum uterine bleeding. It is given intramuscularly and is effective within 1-5 minutes. It is given at the time of delivery of the placenta or immediately after if bleeding is significant. Side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in patients with a history of bronchial asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the below condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

The figure shows clinical picture of dermal vascular necrosis, also known as ‘purple toe syndrome’. It is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

 

Dermal Vascular Necrosis

 

  • Warfarin-induced dermal vascular necrosis is a rare complication of warfarin therapy.
  • It characterized by the development of painful skin lesions in patients taking warfarin.
  • It is thought to be caused by a transient hypercoagulable state resulting from a rapid reduction in protein C levels in patients with underlying protein C deficiency or other risk factors.
  • The lesions typically occur in areas with a high concentration of adipose tissue, such as the breasts, thighs, and buttocks.
  • The initial symptoms include red or purple spots on the skin that can quickly progress to painful, necrotic lesions with a central blister or eschar.
  • The diagnosis is usually made clinically based on the characteristic appearance of the lesions and the patient's history of warfarin therapy.
  • The treatment of dermal vascular necrosis involves stopping warfarin and initiating alternative anticoagulant therapy, such as heparin or low molecular weight heparin.
  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to remove the necrotic tissue and prevent further damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by activating antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis. However, heparin can cause other complications such as heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an anticoagulant. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is generally associated with a different profile of side effects, including bleeding.

 

Option D. Rivaroxaban: Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor used for anticoagulation. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is associated with a different side effect profile, mainly related to bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin can cause dermal vascular necrosis, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency, presenting as painful, necrotic skin lesions shortly after initiation of therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a focal non-cicatricial cause of alopecia? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cicatricial (scarring) form of alopecia, not a non-cicatricial cause. 

 

 

  • DLE destroys hair follicles, leading to permanent hair loss with scarring. 
  • It's specifically classified under "Connective tissue diseases" in scarring alopecias. 
  • When DLE affects the scalp, it leads to inflammatory lesions that heal with scarring, resulting in irreversible hair loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • This is correctly classified as a non-cicatricial alopecia. 
  • It's characterized by circular patches of complete hair loss with exclamation mark hairs at the periphery. 

 

 

  • Hair follicles remain preserved, making it potentially reversible.

 

Option B. Secondary Syphilis:

 

  • Secondary syphilis can cause a moth-eaten, patchy pattern of hair loss, which is non-cicatricial. 

 

 

Option C. Black Dot Type Tinea Capitis:

 

  • This is a non-inflammatory type of tinea capitis where infected hairs break off at the scalp surface, leaving behind characteristic black dots.

 

 

  • It is non-cicatricial, as there is no permanent follicular damage. 
  • However, other inflammatory forms of tinea capitis like kerion (boggy inflammatory mass) and favus (yellow cup-shaped crusts) can destroy hair follicles and cause cicatricial alopecia if not treated early.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cause of focal cicatricial alopecia and thus is not classified among focal non-cicatricial causes of hair loss.

questions.text: A victim of road traffic accident (RTA) presents with fracture of hand with hypothenar atrophy. Nerve involved in him is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • In the hand, the ulnar nerve gives motor innervation to the hypothenar (palmaris brevis, abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi) and the thenar (adductor pollicis, deep head of flexor pollicis brevis) muscles. 
  • Also, it supplies the palmar and dorsal interossei and medial 2 lumbricals.
  • The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist, resulting in motor and sensory loss.
  • Mechanisms of injury include trauma like motor vehicle accident; nerve impingement; lacerations at the wrist; and Guyon’s canal cyst.
  • A motor vehicle accident resulting in a fracture of the metacarpal or phalanges can lead to injury of the ulnar nerve.
  • This is indicated by the atrophy of the hypothenar muscles, leading to flattening of the hypothenar eminence. 
  • Other clinical features of ulnar nerve injury include:
    • Loss of hypothenar eminence
    • Loss of adduction of thumb
    • Loss of abduction of fingers
    • Clawing of 4th and 5th digits

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand. Injury to this nerve would typically result in wrist drop due to loss of extensor muscle function, not hypothenar atrophy. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles in the upper arm. Its involvement would affect arm flexion and not the hypothenar muscles.

 

Option D. Median nerve: The median nerve supplies the thenar eminence and the first two lumbricals. Injury to this nerve would result in issues with thumb opposition and grip, but not hypothenar atrophy.

 

Additional Information: 

 

  • Flexor pollicis brevis superficial head is supplied by median nerve and deep head is supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • The first and second lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve.
  • The third and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • When the lumbricals are paralyzed, they can result in a deformity known as a "claw hand."
  • Ulnar or median nerve injury can lead to a deformity known as "claw hand."
  • Among these, ulnar nerve palsy is more commonly associated with claw hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypothenar atrophy is a clinical sign of ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: A patient with mild to moderate renal failure requires reversal of muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

 

Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant used during surgeries to facilitate intubation and muscle relaxation. After the procedure, it is often necessary to reverse the effects of vecuronium to allow the patient to regain muscle function.

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) specifically designed to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, including vecuronium and rocuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecules, effectively reducing their availability to bind to nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing muscle paralysis.

 

Sugammadex is preferred in patients with mild to moderate renal failure because it is highly effective and works faster than traditional agents like neostigmine. While Sugammadex is contraindicated in severe or end-stage renal disease due to reduced clearance, it can be safely used in mild to moderate renal impairment.

 

Note –

 

Reversal agents for muscle relaxants used in anesthesia include neostigmine and Sugammadex.

 

Neostigmine:

 

  • A cholinergic drug that inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to increased acetylcholine.
  • Causes cholinergic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine.
  • Can be used for all muscle relaxants.
  • Can be given in renal disease patients
  • If neostigmine is not an option and the patient has mild to moderate renal failure, Sugammadex is the preferred choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is primarily used to reverse the effects of central nervous system depressants and is not typically used for reversing non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium.

 

Option B. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is used in the management of Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia, not for reversing muscle relaxants.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used for short-term muscle relaxation, such as during intubation. It is not used for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium and, in fact, would induce more muscle relaxation rather than reverse it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the appropriate agent for reversing the effects of vecuronium in patients with mild to moderate renal failure due to its specific action on non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and its faster onset of action.

questions.text: Delusions are commonly observed in all of the following conditions, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Conversion Disorder

 

Explanation: 

 

Conversion Disorder (also called Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder or Dissociative Neurological Symptom Disorder in ICD-11) is characterized by neurological symptoms like paralysis, blindness, or seizures that cannot be explained by medical conditions. Importantly, delusions are not a feature of conversion disorder. Conversion disorder involves a psychological stressor that manifests as physical symptoms, but the patient does not have false, fixed beliefs (delusions) about their condition.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Schizophrenia (Incorrect): Delusions are core symptoms of schizophrenia. According to the DSM-5 criteria, delusions are one of the characteristic positive symptoms required for diagnosis.
  • Option B. Depression (Incorrect): Delusions can develop in a patient with depression. These may include delusions of guilt, nihilistic delusions (e.g., believing internal organs have rotted), or delusions of poverty.
  • Option C. Dementia (Incorrect): Delusions can occur in dementia, particularly in moderate to severe stages. These are usually transient and less complex than those seen in primary psychotic disorders. Common delusions in dementia include persecutory delusions, delusions of theft, or misidentification delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusions are common features of psychotic disorders like schizophrenia, severe mood disorders with psychotic features (including depression), and neurocognitive disorders like dementia. Conversion disorder, however, is characterized by unexplained neurological symptoms without the presence of delusions, as it belongs to the somatic symptom/dissociative disorder category rather than the psychotic spectrum.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should she discontinue? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

 

These medications are contraindicated during pregnancy because they are associated with fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Therefore, women who are planning to conceive should discontinue these medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labetalol: Labetalol is generally safe for use during pregnancy and is a treatment option for hypertension in pregnant women. It is not necessary to discontinue this medication.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers like nifedipine are also generally considered safe during pregnancy and are often used to manage hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Option D. Alpha methyldopa: Alpha methyldopa is also considered safe during pregnancy and is commonly used for managing hypertension in this population.

 

Given the woman's intention to conceive, discontinuing Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors would be the most appropriate course of action to protect both her health and that of her future child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors should be discontinued in women who are planning to conceive due to their associated risks of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Alternative antihypertensive medications that are safer during pregnancy include labetalol, calcium channel blockers, and alpha methyldopa.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

The given clinical scenario of white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient using inhalational steroids points to diagnosis of oral candidiasis and drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.

 

Asthma patients use MDI which can result in deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which might lead to cough, dysphonia, and oral candidiasis.

 

Clotrimazole is classified under Azole group of Anti-Fungal drugs, acts by inhibiting fungal sterol (ergosterol) synthesis. Used topically in treatment for topical fungal infections like tinea and candida

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is mainly used against dermatophytes and is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. But it is not effective against Candida.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Terbinafine acts by inhibiting the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase. which reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. Used to treat nail onychomycosis and other dermatophytosis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: Flucytosine acts by inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis. Used exclusively to combat systemic fungal infections (e.g., cryptococcal meningitis) in combination with amphotericin B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with good prognosis in schizophrenia, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Predominant Negative symptoms

 

Explanation: Predominant negative symptoms are associated with poor prognosis in schizophrenia, not good prognosis. Negative symptoms (often remembered as the "6As") include avolition (loss of drive), apathy (lack of concern), anhedonia (loss of pleasure), asociality (lack of social interaction), affective flattening (lack of emotional response), and alogia (decreased verbal communication). These symptoms respond poorly to medications and are considered poor prognostic factors.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Late onset (Incorrect): Advanced age of onset (>35 years) is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia. Early onset (<20 years) is linked to poorer outcomes.
  • Option B. Presence of Depression (Incorrect): The presence of affective symptoms, including depression, is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia.
  • Option D. Acute onset (Incorrect): Acute or abrupt onset of symptoms is associated with better prognosis compared to insidious onset.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Good prognostic factors in schizophrenia include acute/abrupt onset, later age of onset (>35 years), female gender, presence of affective symptoms, and predominant positive symptoms. Poor prognostic factors include insidious onset, early onset (<20 years), male gender, predominant negative symptoms, and absence of affective symptoms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the goal is to prevent lactation to avoid discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. The appropriate treatment involves using a drug that can suppress prolactin secretion, as prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively suppressing lactation. It is often used for this purpose and can be an effective choice in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a direct role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can increase prolactin levels, which would not be helpful in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and antiemetic that also increases prolactin levels, making it unsuitable for suppressing lactation.

 

Given these options, the correct choice for preventing lactation and thus avoiding the associated complications is: b. Cabergoline

choices.text: NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available
NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

questions.text: The image of the mascot ‘Sapna’ shown below and identify what does she represent in the national health program: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

 

'Sapna' is the mascot of National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP) in India. She represents the success story of leprosy treatment, as she herself was a leprosy patient who got completely cured after taking multi-drug therapy (MDT). Her role is to spread awareness about:

 

  • Curability of leprosy through MDT
  • Reducing stigma and discrimination associated with leprosy in society
  • Encouraging early detection and treatment seeking behavior
  • Demonstrating that leprosy patients can lead a normal life after treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available: Incorrect because there is no widely accepted vaccine for leprosy currently available for public use

 

Option B. NLEP, Leprosy has been eliminated: While India achieved elimination status (<1 case/10,000 population) in December 2005, the program continues as new cases still occur

 

Option D. NLEP, leprosy can't affect children: Incorrect as leprosy can affect people of any age group including children

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sapna is the mascot of NLEP who represents successful treatment of leprosy and aims to reduce stigma while spreading awareness about curability of the disease through multi-drug therapy.

questions.text: All of the following are true about dementia and differentiate it from delirium, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Clouding of consciousness

 

Explanation: 

 

Clouding of consciousness is a characteristic feature of delirium, not dementia. The disturbance of consciousness is considered one of the hallmark symptoms of delirium and represents a key distinguishing feature between these two neurocognitive disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Insidious onset (Incorrect): Dementia typically has an insidious onset with gradual progression, while delirium has a sudden onset. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • Option B. Often irreversible (Incorrect): Most dementias are irreversible and progressive conditions, unlike delirium which is usually reversible if the underlying cause is identified and treated. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • Option D. Impaired remote memory (Incorrect): In dementia, memory impairment follows a pattern where recent memory is affected first, followed by immediate memory, and finally remote memory in later stages. In delirium, immediate and recent memory are primarily affected while remote memory remains relatively intact. Impaired remote memory in later stages is a feature of dementia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key differences between dementia and delirium include: dementia has insidious onset and progressive course while delirium has sudden onset and fluctuating course; consciousness is preserved in dementia but disturbed in delirium; and dementia is often irreversible whereas delirium is usually reversible when the underlying cause is treated.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause a pleural pathology? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used primarily in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is not associated with pleural pathologies, making it the correct choice in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methysergide: Methysergide is a medication used to prevent migraine headaches and is known for its potential to cause retroperitoneal and pleural fibrosis. This pleural pathology is a serious adverse effect, although the drug is not commonly used today due to this risk.

 

Option C. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of various cancers. One of its well-known side effects is pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pulmonary fibrosis. Pleural involvement, including pleural effusions and fibrosis, can occur secondary to its pulmonary effects.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic used primarily for urinary tract infections. It can cause pulmonary reactions, including acute, subacute, and chronic pulmonary reactions. These reactions can involve the pleura, leading to pleural effusions and other pleural pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is not associated with causing pleural pathologies, unlike Methysergide, Bleomycin, and Nitrofurantoin, which have known risks of causing pleural and pulmonary complications.

questions.text: Theophylline was prescribed to a male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The next day, he noticed that his urine output had increased. Which of the following receptors is responsible for the drug's action? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine A1

 

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that primarily acts as a nonselective adenosine receptor antagonist. By antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, theophylline can lead to diuresis or increased urine output. Adenosine normally promotes water reabsorption in the renal tubules, and its blockade by theophylline results in increased urine production. This mechanism is separate from its therapeutic action in COPD, which involves bronchodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interleukin-10: Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine. It is not a direct target of theophylline. IL-10 plays a role in regulating immune responses, but it is not involved in the diuretic effect or the primary action of theophylline in COPD treatment.

 

Option B. Histone Deacetylase: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) is an enzyme involved in chromatin remodelling and gene expression regulation. While theophylline has been suggested to have some modulatory effects on HDAC, especially in the context of COPD and asthma, it is not the mechanism responsible for the increased urine output observed in the patient.

 

Option D. Beta 2 Adrenergic Receptors: While theophylline has mild bronchodilatory effects thought to be mediated through inhibition of phosphodiesterase (increasing cAMP levels in smooth muscle), leading to relaxation of bronchial smooth muscles, beta 2 adrenergic receptors are more specifically targeted by drugs like salbutamol. Theophylline's diuretic effect is not mediated through beta 2 adrenergic receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Theophylline increases urine output by antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, leading to decreased water reabsorption in the renal tubules and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: What is the term for a primary skin lesion that is flat, without elevation or depression, and less than 1 cm in diameter? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macule

 

  • A macule is a circumscribed, flat lesion of skin that is visible because of a change in skin color. 

 

 

  • It is neither elevated nor depressed, has no change in skin texture, and by definition is less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Macules can be hyperpigmented (like fixed drug eruption), hypopigmented (like leprosy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papule 

 

  • A papule is a small, solid, elevated lesion less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Unlike macules, papules project above the skin surface and 

 

Option C. Patch 

 

  • A patch is similar to a macule in that it is flat and has a color change, but by definition, a patch is larger than 1 cm in diameter. 

 

Option D. Vesicle 

 

  • A vesicle is a fluid-filled, circumscribed, elevated lesion less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Vesicles form due to a split in the skin and contain clear fluid.

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • A macule is a flat, non-palpable, circumscribed lesion less than 1 cm in diameter that represents a change in skin color without alteration in skin texture or thickness.

choices.text: To prevent teratogenic effects
To avoid failure of ATT
Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism
Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with tuberculosis and is about to begin antitubercular therapy (ATT) that includes rifampicin. She is currently taking oral contraceptives (OCP) for birth control. The clinician advises her to use an additional barrier method of contraception while undergoing treatment. What is the primary reason for this recommendation? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

 

Rifampicin is used as one of the first line drugs against tuberculosis. Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer, that induces the cytochrome P450 enzymes. Therefore, this leads to increased rate of metabolism of the OCPs, thereby leading to contraceptive failure. So, in a female receiving ATT, it is advised to use additional barrier methods of contraception apart from OCPs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. To prevent teratogenic effects: Most of the antitubercular drugs including rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol are safe in pregnancy. Further she is already taking OCPs, so the examiner does not want to ask about teratogenic effect of antitubercular drugs.

 

Option B. To avoid failure of ATT: The interaction between ATT and OCP does not lead to the failure of antitubercular therapy; rather, it affects the efficacy of the oral contraceptive method.

 

Option C. Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism: This is incorrect because rifampicin actually induces, rather than decreases, the metabolism of oral contraceptives. This can lead to reduced levels of contraceptive hormones in the blood, thereby potentially leading to contraceptive failure.

 

Educational Objective

 

Rifampicin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that speed up the metabolism of various drugs, including oral contraceptives. This can lead to lower blood levels of the hormones in OCPs, thereby reducing their efficacy and increasing the risk of contraceptive failure. Hence, it is advised for patients on both medications to use an additional barrier method of contraception.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects does the drug have on the fetus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Premature closure of ductus arteriosus

 

Indomethacin is an NSAID, that acts by inhibiting the Cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme, thereby decreasing the synthesis of Prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are necessary for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus. Therefore, Indomethacin if given to a pregnant woman can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keeps ductus arteriosus patent: Indomethacin does not keep the ductus arteriosus patent; instead, it promotes its closure by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

 

Option C. Closure of fossa ovalis: The closure of the fossa ovalis is not influenced by indomethacin. The fossa ovalis is a different fetal structure that closes postnatally due to changes in pressure gradients.

 

Option D. Premature closure of ductus venous: The ductus venosus closure is not affected by indomethacin. This structure typically closes naturally after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indomethacin, an NSAID, can cause the premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in a fetus due to its inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Therefore, caution should be exercised when prescribing this drug to pregnant women, particularly in the third trimester.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • The given image shows the Codman’s triangle which is a characteristic radiological finding in osteosarcoma. 
  • Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction, seen on X-ray, characterized by the lifting of the periosteum with a triangular piece of dense calcification underneath. 
  • This appearance is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction. 
  • It is commonly associated with malignant lesions or chronic processes, with osteosarcoma being a typical example.
  • Sun Ray Appearance is another X-ray finding where there are multiple radiating spicules extending from a bone, resembling rays of the sun. 

 

Note - While these periosteal reactions are highly suggestive of certain bone conditions, they are not diagnostic on their own. The definitive diagnosis of bone lesions, whether benign or malignant, is confirmed through a tissue biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma can show aggressive periosteal reactions such as an onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: This is a benign bone growth that typically have a distinct appearance with an exostosis pointing away from the joint.

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: This condition can show a periosteal reaction, but it is usually a solid, narrow zone reaction and not the wide zone reaction like Codman's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to impair scholastic performance? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. PICA

 

Explanation: 

 

PICA is an eating disorder characterized by the persistent consumption of non-nutritive, non-food substances (such as dirt, clay, paper, paint chips, etc.) that is inappropriate for the developmental level of the individual. While PICA can have health consequences due to ingestion of potentially harmful substances, it does not directly impact cognitive functions or learning abilities in the way the other listed conditions do. Therefore, PICA is least likely to directly impair scholastic performance.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Incorrect): ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. These symptoms directly interfere with learning processes, classroom behavior, and academic achievement. Children with ADHD often struggle with focusing during lessons, completing assignments, following instructions, and staying organized, all of which significantly impact scholastic performance.
  • Option B. Specific Learning Disability (SLD) (Incorrect): SLD is defined by significant impairment in one or more specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) despite normal intellectual functioning. By definition, SLD directly impacts scholastic performance, as it specifically affects the acquisition and use of academic skills.
  • Option C. Anxiety (Incorrect): Anxiety disorders can significantly impair scholastic performance through several mechanisms. Test anxiety can lead to underperformance in examinations, social anxiety can interfere with class participation and group activities, and generalized anxiety can affect concentration, working memory, and overall cognitive functioning in the classroom setting.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When considering psychiatric disorders that impact academic performance, it's important to differentiate between conditions that directly affect cognitive functions, learning processes, or classroom behavior (like ADHD, learning disabilities, and anxiety) versus conditions that primarily affect other domains of functioning (like certain eating disorders). PICA, as an eating disorder characterized by consumption of non-food substances, has physiological and health implications but does not directly impact the cognitive processes essential for learning.
